H0.text: What substance, best known as a poison, was used in small doses in medications as a stimulant, as a laxative, and for enhancing performance in sports. Arsenic

H1.text: What substance, best known as a poison, was used in small doses in medications as a stimulant, as a laxative, and for enhancing performance in sports. Mercury

H2.text: What substance, best known as a poison, was used in small doses in medications as a stimulant, as a laxative, and for enhancing performance in sports. Cyanide

H3.text: What substance, best known as a poison, was used in small doses in medications as a stimulant, as a laxative, and for enhancing performance in sports. Stricnine

A4.text: In small doses, soluble arsenic compounds act as stimulants, and were once popular as medicine by people in the mid-18th to 19th centuries; this use was especially prevalent for sport animals such as race horses or work dogs and continued into the 20th century.

A5.text: During the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries, a number of arsenic compounds were used as medicines, including arsphenamine (by Paul Ehrlich) and arsenic trioxide (by Thomas Fowler), for treating diseases such as cancer or psoriasis.
